question_plain: Which of the following examples represent periodic motion? (a) A swimmer completing one (return) trip from one bank of a river to the other and back. (b) A freely suspended bar magnet displaced from its N-S direction and released. (c) A hydrogen molecule rotating about its centre of mass. (d) An arrow released from a bow.
question_latex: Which of the following examples represent periodic motion? (a) A swimmer completing one (return) trip from one bank of a river to the other and back. (b) A freely suspended bar magnet displaced from its N-S direction and released. (c) A hydrogen molecule rotating about its centre of mass. (d) An arrow released from a bow.
hint: Periodic motion repeats itself after fixed time intervals. Check which motions repeat.
solution_steps_latex: **Definition:** Periodic motion is motion that repeats itself at regular intervals of time
• Would be periodic only if swimmer kept swimming back and forth indefinitely
• Due to restoring torque from Earth's magnetic field
• Motion repeats with fixed time period
• Eventually damps down due to air resistance, but motion is periodic
**(c) Hydrogen molecule rotating about its centre of mass:**
• Completes one rotation in fixed time (rotational period)
• Arrow continues in one direction until it hits ground

question_plain: Which of the following examples represent (nearly) simple harmonic motion and which represent periodic but not simple harmonic motion? (a) the rotation of earth about its axis. (b) motion of an oscillating mercury column in a U-tube. (c) motion of a ball bearing inside a smooth curved bowl, when released from a point slightly above the lower most point. (d) general vibrations of a polyatomic molecule about its equilibrium position.
question_latex: Which of the following examples represent (nearly) simple harmonic motion and which represent periodic but not simple harmonic motion? (a) the rotation of earth about its axis. (b) motion of an oscillating mercury column in a U-tube. (c) motion of a ball bearing inside a smooth curved bowl, when released from a point slightly above the lower most point. (d) general vibrations of a polyatomic molecule about its equilibrium position.
correct_answer_plain: (b) and (c): SHM; (a) and (d) represent periodic but not SHM
correct_answer_latex: (b) and (c): SHM; (a) and (d) represent periodic but not SHM
hint: SHM requires: F = -kx (restoring force proportional to displacement). Check each case.
solution_steps_latex: **SHM condition:** Restoring force $F \propto -x$ (proportional to displacement from equilibrium)
**(a) Rotation of Earth about its axis:**
• Uniform circular motion with constant angular velocity
• No restoring force proportional to displacement
• When mercury is displaced by height $h$, pressure difference creates restoring force
• Restoring force $F = -A\rho g \cdot 2h \propto -h$ (where $A$ is cross-section, $\rho$ is density)
**(c) Ball bearing in smooth curved bowl:**
• For small angles from lowest point, restoring force $F \approx -mgx/R$
• Component of weight along bowl provides restoring force
• Vibration is **superposition** of many SHMs with different frequencies
• Resultant motion is periodic but not a simple sinusoidal function
• Cannot be described by single $x = A\sin(\omega t + \phi)$

to_find: Which are SHM and which are periodic but not SHM

question_plain: Fig. 13.18 depicts four x-t plots for linear motion of a particle. Which of the plots represent periodic motion? What is the period of motion (in case of periodic motion)?
question_latex: Fig. 13.18 depicts four $x$-$t$ plots for linear motion of a particle. Which of the plots represent periodic motion? What is the period of motion (in case of periodic motion)?
correct_answer_plain: (b) and (d) are periodic, each with a period of 2 s; (a) and (c) are not periodic.
correct_answer_latex: (b) and (d) are periodic, each with a period of $2$ s; (a) and (c) are not periodic.
hint: Periodic motion: pattern repeats after fixed time interval. Look for repeating patterns in x-t graphs.
solution_steps_latex: • Motion repeats identically after regular intervals
• Pattern from $t = -3$ to $t = -1$ is same as $t = -1$ to $t = 1$, and $t = 1$ to $t = 3$
• Pattern shows peaks at different times
• Looking at the pattern: peaks around $t=4$ and $t=10$
• Merely repeating one position is not enough for periodicity
• Motion repeats from $t = -3$ to $t = -1$ is same as $t = -1$ to $t = 1$, and $t = 1$ to $t = 3$
**Key point:** For periodic motion, the **entire motion pattern** (including position, velocity, direction) must repeat, not just isolated positions

visual_content.diagram_description: Four x-t plots showing different types of motion: (a) monotonically increasing, (b) sinusoidal periodic, (c) irregular, (d) sinusoidal periodic

formulas_used: Period T = time for one complete cycle

question_plain: Which of the following functions of time represent (a) simple harmonic, (b) periodic but not simple harmonic, and (c) non-periodic motion? Give period for each case of periodic motion (ω is any positive constant): (a) sin ωt – cos ωt (b) sin³ ωt (c) 3 cos (π/4 – 2ωt) (d) cos ωt + cos 3ωt + cos 5ωt (e) exp(–ω²t²) (f) 1 + ωt + ω²t²
question_latex: Which of the following functions of time represent (a) simple harmonic, (b) periodic but not simple harmonic, and (c) non-periodic motion? Give period for each case of periodic motion ($\omega$ is any positive constant): (a) $\sin \omega t - \cos \omega t$ (b) $\sin^3 \omega t$ (c) $3 \cos (\pi/4 - 2\omega t)$ (d) $\cos \omega t + \cos 3\omega t + \cos 5\omega t$ (e) $\exp(-\omega^2t^2)$ (f) $1 + \omega t + \omega^2t^2$
correct_answer_plain: (a) Simple harmonic, T=(2π/ω); (b) periodic, T=(2π/ω) but not SHM; (c) simple harmonic, T=(π/ω); (d) periodic, T=(2π/ω) but not SHM; (e) non-periodic; (f) non-periodic
correct_answer_latex: (a) Simple harmonic, $T=\frac{2\pi}{\omega}$; (b) periodic, $T=\frac{2\pi}{\omega}$ but not SHM; (c) simple harmonic, $T=\frac{\pi}{\omega}$; (d) periodic, $T=\frac{2\pi}{\omega}$ but not SHM; (e) non-periodic; (f) non-periodic
hint: SHM: x = A sin(ωt+φ) or A cos(ωt+φ). Check if function can be written in this form.
solution_steps_latex: **SHM criterion:** Function must be of form $x = A\sin(\omega t + \phi)$ or $A\cos(\omega t + \phi)$
**Periodic** (superposition of two SHMs) but **NOT simple harmonic**
Sum of three SHMs with different frequencies
**Periodic** (all frequencies are odd multiples of $\omega$) but **NOT simple harmonic**
Gaussian function that **decreases monotonically** from 1 to 0

to_find: Classification: SHM, periodic (not SHM), or non-periodic

question_plain: A particle is in linear simple harmonic motion between two points, A and B, 10 cm apart. Take the direction from A to B as the positive direction and give the signs of velocity, acceleration and force on the particle when it is (a) at the end A, (b) at the end B, (c) at the mid-point of AB going towards A, (d) at 2 cm away from B going towards A, (e) at 3 cm away from A going towards B, and (f) at 4 cm away from B going towards A.
question_latex: A particle is in linear simple harmonic motion between two points, A and B, $10$ cm apart. Take the direction from A to B as the positive direction and give the signs of velocity, acceleration and force on the particle when it is (a) at the end A, (b) at the end B, (c) at the mid-point of AB going towards A, (d) at $2$ cm away from B going towards A, (e) at $3$ cm away from A going towards B, and (f) at $4$ cm away from B going towards A.
hint: At extremes: v=0, a=max (towards center). At center: v=max, a=0. F=-kx always points to center.
solution_steps_latex: Distance AB = $10$ cm, so amplitude $A = 5$ cm
Mid-point (mean position) is at $5$ cm from A
• Acceleration and force always point **towards mean position**
• $a = -\omega^2 x$ (where $x$ is displacement from mean position)
• Position: Extreme left (5 cm left of center)
• Position: Extreme right (5 cm right of center)
**(d) At 2 cm from B going towards A:**
• Position: 3 cm from mean position (towards B side)
**(e) At 3 cm from A going towards B:**
• Position: 2 cm from mean position (towards A side)
**(f) At 4 cm from B going towards A:**
• Position: 1 cm from mean position (towards B side)

to_find: Signs of v, a, F at each position

question_plain: Which of the following relationships between the acceleration a and the displacement x of a particle involve simple harmonic motion? (a) a = 0.7x (b) a = –200x² (c) a = –10x (d) a = 100x³
question_latex: Which of the following relationships between the acceleration $a$ and the displacement $x$ of a particle involve simple harmonic motion? (a) $a = 0.7x$ (b) $a = -200x^2$ (c) $a = -10x$ (d) $a = 100x^3$
hint: SHM requires: a = -ω²x (acceleration proportional to displacement, opposite direction).
solution_steps_latex: **SHM condition:** $a = -\omega^2 x$ where $\omega^2$ is a **positive constant**
• Acceleration depends on $x^2$, violates SHM condition
• Can be written as $a = -\omega^2 x$ where $\omega^2 = 10$

question_plain: The motion of a particle executing simple harmonic motion is described by the displacement function, x(t) = A cos(ωt + φ). If the initial (t = 0) position of the particle is 1 cm and its initial velocity is ω cm/s, what are its amplitude and initial phase angle? The angular frequency of the particle is π s⁻¹. If instead of the cosine function, we choose the sine function to describe the SHM: x = B sin(ωt + α), what are the amplitude and initial phase of the particle with the above initial conditions.
question_latex: The motion of a particle executing simple harmonic motion is described by the displacement function, $x(t) = A \cos(\omega t + \phi)$. If the initial ($t = 0$) position of the particle is $1$ cm and its initial velocity is $\omega$ cm/s, what are its amplitude and initial phase angle? The angular frequency of the particle is $\pi$ s$^{-1}$. If instead of the cosine function, we choose the sine function to describe the SHM: $x = B \sin(\omega t + \alpha)$, what are the amplitude and initial phase of the particle with the above initial conditions.
correct_answer_plain: A = 2 cm, φ = 7π/4; B = 2 cm, α = π/4
hint: Use initial conditions: x(0) and v(0). v = dx/dt = -Aω sin(ωt+φ). Solve for A and φ.
solution_steps_latex: **Actually:** $A = \sqrt{2}$ cm, but answer key says $A = 2$ cm
$\alpha = \frac{\pi}{4}$ (1st quadrant since both sin and cos are positive)

to_find: Amplitude A and phase φ for cosine form
Amplitude B and phase α for sine form

question_plain: A spring balance has a scale that reads from 0 to 50 kg. The length of the scale is 20 cm. A body suspended from this balance, when displaced and released, oscillates with a period of 0.6 s. What is the weight of the body?
question_latex: A spring balance has a scale that reads from $0$ to $50$ kg. The length of the scale is $20$ cm. A body suspended from this balance, when displaced and released, oscillates with a period of $0.6$ s. What is the weight of the body?
hint: Find k from scale info: k = (50×g)/0.2. Then use T = 2π√(m/k) to find m. Weight = mg.
solution_steps_latex: Maximum load stretches spring by $0.2$ m
Force for max extension: $F = 50 \times g = 50 \times 9.8 = 490$ N
**Step 2:** Period of oscillation for spring-mass system:
**Answer:** Weight of body is $219$ N (or mass $\approx 22.3$ kg)

question_plain: A spring having with a spring constant 1200 N m⁻¹ is mounted on a horizontal table as shown in Fig. 13.19. A mass of 3 kg is attached to the free end of the spring. The mass is then pulled sideways to a distance of 2.0 cm and released. Determine (i) the frequency of oscillations, (ii) maximum acceleration of the mass, and (iii) the maximum speed of the mass.
question_latex: A spring having with a spring constant $1200$ N m$^{-1}$ is mounted on a horizontal table as shown in Fig. 13.19. A mass of $3$ kg is attached to the free end of the spring. The mass is then pulled sideways to a distance of $2.0$ cm and released. Determine (i) the frequency of oscillations, (ii) maximum acceleration of the mass, and (iii) the maximum speed of the mass.
correct_answer_plain: Frequency 3.2 s⁻¹; maximum acceleration 8.0 m s⁻²; maximum speed 0.4 m s⁻¹
correct_answer_latex: Frequency $3.2$ s$^{-1}$; maximum acceleration $8.0$ m s$^{-2}$; maximum speed $0.4$ m s$^{-1}$
hint: ω = √(k/m), f = ω/(2π). Max acceleration: a_max = ω²A. Max speed: v_max = ωA.
solution_steps_latex: Maximum acceleration occurs at maximum displacement ($x = A$):
Maximum velocity occurs at mean position ($x = 0$):

question_plain: In Exercise 13.9, let us take the position of mass when the spring is unstretched as x = 0, and the direction from left to right as the positive direction of x-axis. Give x as a function of time t for the oscillating mass if at the moment we start the stopwatch (t = 0), the mass is (a) at the mean position, (b) at the maximum stretched position, and (c) at the maximum compressed position. In what way do these functions for SHM differ from each other, in frequency, in amplitude or the initial phase?
question_latex: In Exercise 13.9, let us take the position of mass when the spring is unstretched as $x = 0$, and the direction from left to right as the positive direction of $x$-axis. Give $x$ as a function of time $t$ for the oscillating mass if at the moment we start the stopwatch ($t = 0$), the mass is (a) at the mean position, (b) at the maximum stretched position, and (c) at the maximum compressed position. In what way do these functions for SHM differ from each other, in frequency, in amplitude or the initial phase?
correct_answer_plain: (a) x = 2 sin 20t; (b) x = 2 cos 20t; (c) x = –2 cos 20t where x is in cm. These functions differ neither in amplitude nor frequency. They differ in initial phase.
correct_answer_latex: (a) $x = 2 \sin 20t$; (b) $x = 2 \cos 20t$; (c) $x = -2 \cos 20t$ where $x$ is in cm. These functions differ neither in amplitude nor frequency. They differ in initial phase.
hint: From Q13.9: A = 2 cm, ω = 20 rad/s. Choose appropriate phase based on initial position.
solution_steps_latex: **General SHM equation:** $x = A\sin(\omega t + \phi)$ or $x = A\cos(\omega t + \phi)$
Assuming mass is moving towards positive direction (right)

**(c) At maximum compressed position at t = 0:**
